column4: that's foolish.  there is only one mbr that matters, the one on /dev/hda
that makes no sense at all
by that logic, if you install ubuntu on /dev/hdb1 you would use the mbr on /dev/hdb
which is obvious nonsense.  such an idea about sda is equally obviously nonsense
it's another situation... whet you install ubuntu on /dev/sda, then bootloader will be on /dev/hda......
and this is wrong i think...
what you don't understand is that it is _not_ a different situation.
the only  mbr that matters is the one the bios uses to boot the machine.
it makes no difference which piece of hardware you happen to choose to put anything on, be it linux or ubuntu or any other o/s
my /dev/hda has 500MB and /dev/sda 80GB... where can i install ubuntu?
you can install anywhere you like
that has nothing to do with which boot sector should be modified
what about it?  I don't believe it's correct.  you do.
